title: Essex lorry deaths: Face of agony as dad sobs for son feared to be among victims
text:

A father's overwhelming agony that his son may be among those who died in the doomed Essex lorry trailer has been laid bare in devastating photos.

Le Van Ha left his poor and agricultural village in Vietnam in search of a better life in the UK, but his family have not heard from him since he embarked on the journey.

The 30-year-old's wife is also struggling to come to terms with the thought she may never see him again and can barely eat or speak as the family awaits any flicker of information.

Dad Le Minh Tuan is convinced his son is one of the 39 migrants found dead in the early hours of Wednesday in a refrigerated container at Waterglade Industrial Park in Grays, Essex.

Heartbreaking photos show the agony etched upon his face as he sobs while clutching his young grandson.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

"He's left us with a huge debt," he said.

"I don't know when we can ever pay it back. I'm an old man now, my health is poor, and I have to help bring up his children."

Although his son's death has not been confirmed, the family are slowly giving up hope of good news.

Inside their modest home, Le Van Ha's grandmother stares blankly and covers her face with her hands.

While Le Van Ha's wife Ha is so consumed with grief she cannot eat or muster up the energy to speak.

The young man left for Europe three months ago, just before the birth of his second son, reports the BBC.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

His family mortgaged two plots of land to pay the £20,000 fee for his journey to the UK. The plan was for Le Van Ha to repay them once he found a good job - but their world has fallen apart.

The last contact Le Minh Tuan had with his son was a Facebook message saying he was about to leave for England.

Meanwhile, the painstaking process of identifying the bodies is still underway.

Investigators will look at tattoos, scars and belongings, including jewellery and clothing, with each of the victims said to have had some kind of bag.

(Image: PA)

(Image: PA)

More than 500 exhibits have been collected, including mobile phones, which will be downloaded and interrogated for any messages that could give clues to the identity of the victims, or how they came to be in the back of the trailer.

Families face an agonising wait to find out if their loved ones were among the dead after Essex Police launched "the largest mass fatality victim identification process" in the force's history.

Officers initially believed they were all Chinese nationals, but a representative of VietHome - a website for Vietnamese people in the UK - said it has passed on the pictures of almost 20 people who have been reported missing to police.

(Image: PA)

Police said they are investigating a "wider conspiracy" after claims surfaced that the lorry could have been part of a convoy of three carrying around 100 people.

Truck driver Maurice Robinson, 25, who is known as Mo, is due to appear at Chelmsford Magistrates Court today (Monday).

The 25-year-old from Northern Ireland has been charged with 39 counts of manslaughter, conspiracy to traffic people, conspiracy to assist unlawful immigration and money laundering.

A man and woman, both 38, from Warrington, and a 45-year-old man from Northern Ireland, who were arrested last week, have been released on bail.

Last night, Essex Police said a 23-year-old arrested at Dublin Port was a "person of interest" in their investigation.
description: The family of dad-of-two Le Van Ha, 30, are clinging on to any flicker of hope he is still alive after the bodies of 39 migrants were found in a container at an industrial estate in Essex
